title: PyCardano - Build dApps in Python
description: Developers without Haskell experience need to spend months in learning Haskell before they can productively build dApps on Cardano.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer aims to attract Python developers to Cardano with PyCardano. This is aligned to the challenge of “creating a positive developer experience…”.PyCardano is a lightweight Cardano library in Python. Since Haskell has a steep learning curve and since Python is one of the most popular and one of the easiest languages to learn, more developers will be able to create dApps faster on Cardano. I am a part time developer in Python and are always on the lookout for a library that can make my task or project easier instead of learning a new language. New Python developers that may not have much or no blockchain experience may bring new ideas and bring creative solutions to current and future challenges. "The successful adapters were excellent at taking knowledge from one pursuit and applying it creatively to another,... " - Range by David Epstein.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer is an individual and has already created a PyCardano GitHub repository and has a Discord channel with the same name. He also is also the creator for py2hs. This is “a complementary resource that helps python programmers to learn Haskell as a new language”. This demonstrates sound knowledge of the two languages and should give one confidence in his ability that this proposal will be implemented successfully.  
In terms of the budget, 99.25% the proposed amount (US 104,000 out of US 104,781) will go to a senior software engineer with a rate of US 100/ hour. Research suggests that hourly rates in the US ranges from +-US 52/hr to +-US 80/hr. This may indicate that the budgeted amount may be inflated by at least US 20,800 (104,000 – 83,200 (US 80/hr x 40 hours x 26 weeks)). I would suggest lowering the hourly rate to reflect a fair market rate.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is a clear roadmap and timelines in weeks are well defined and clearly indicated. Deliverables are clearly outlined in batches e.g. 6 weeks, 8 weeks etc. The definition of success of for the project is also stated in week chucks. For example, “12 weeks after funding:
•	Developers will be able to use Plutus Python APIs to create and submit script transactions.
•	Developers will be able to use the API to stake the funds locked in Plutus script to any pool.”
Just to name two.
Most of the milestone tracking are possible but for some but they are not. Trackable milestones are:
•	Weekly PyPI downloads of the library reaches 100+.
•	Weekly PyPI downloads of the library reaches 150+.
•	Weekly PyPI downloads of the library reaches 200+
•	Developers will be able to use Plutus Python APIs to create and submit script transactions.
•	Developers will be able to use the API to stake the funds locked in Plutus script to any pool.
•	Developers will be able to use the API to develop basic dApps.
Milestones not trackable are:
•	Developers will be able to use the Python Plutus SDK to create, develop, test, manage, and deploy new dApps in less than a week.
•	Developers will be able to build and deploy a sample dApp in less than 15 minutes.
I would suggest the proposer indicate how he plans to track and display these two milestones.
The proposer explains the risks of writing off-chain code in Python. Plutus is a domain specific language (DSL) created from Haskell with the intention of minimizing the chances of writing bad code. The reason for this is because a DSL can only operate within its intended domain and purpose. This means it cannot do things it’s not supposed to do. The proposer outlines that off-chain Python code will not pose a risk as the on-chain code will still be written in Plutus. This should give confidence to developers to develop dApps safely.

And the proposal did satisfy that purpose by providing Python developers with a library including APIs that assists them to write codes for their apps in Python. The proposal included detailed information about all functions of the library that are handy and beneficial for developers to develop apps in the most convenient and effective way. Besides, a detailed and clear explanation about how advantageous it is to employ this library in order to motivate developers to build apps on Cardano was also well written. They do not need to waste a whole lot of time, several weeks and months, equipping themselves with some knowledge before getting their hands dirty in building apps. This will absolutely encourage developers to build apps on Cardano with the assistance of the library.  Another highlight of this proposal is that it also listed out a sample app to offer readers of this proposal a real experience or a real imagination of the real product if this proposal is funded and executed. However, this proposal would be totally perfect if the proposer mentions more about some risks and some solutions to mitigate those risks entailing more technical aspects and case studies to clarify that they can take control over arising issues along the way executing this project.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aligns with the challenge's objective and HAS a direct impact on the Cardano ecosystem. In comparison, the PyCardano library can effectively facilitate building dApps on Cardano and offers many conveniences to developers in their first step to building a dApp, through the core functionality of the library, as well as two end-to-end educational dApps. In addition, the proposer also made it clear the difficulties Haskell has brought to developers, as it has the potential to slow down their adoption. From there, it shows the effectiveness of this library. It answers the question that the challenge posed and about the impact of using Python on the security of Cardano’s smart contracts. However, I have yet to see the necessary information about the skills and experience needed to carry out the activities mentioned in the proposal, as well as the necessary human resources allocation. Even with the base PyCardano library in place, this project still required the involvement of an effective team, not just engineer Jerry Chan, and I'd love to see a detailed presentation about that team. f6_assessments.q2: Stemming that the process of carrying out activities in the three milestones and the allocation of human resources in the Feasibility part has not been specified, this last part is not really convincing enough for the readers. For example, after your team completes the first milestone, how will the community track this progress and development? How does the community rely on specific KPIs to define that this proposal will be successful? I like the proposer to elaborate on measuring the progress and the development of this project. Otherwise, investors will not have concrete evidence to hope that these successful milestones will occur in the future. Since this is an entirely new Catalyst proposal, through this comment, I hope the proposer can add more to the proposal so that investors can see the seriousness of your team.

f6_assessments.q1:
Pycardano is open-sourced already - by examining the code quality, testing coverage, unit/integration testing set up, example use case provided, it's no doubt the proposer has the knowledge and skillset to continuously enhance the tool. Not only does proposer seem to have good knowledge around Cardano/blockchain but also the knowledge around Cloud technology for software development. Moreover, Jerry has contributed the https://github.com/cffls/py2hs, which is a nice guide for people with python experience to draw analogy learning Haskell, another indicator of proposer being a seasoned developer. 

The budget breakdown is clear - development cost and infrastructure cost. The deliverables are concrete. E.g., two end-to-end dApps for the Educational dApps phase. Given his track record of active code commit, I'm confident in proposer's ability to implement the proposal successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposed roadmap is detailed, reasonable and contains concrete metrics goal that can be easily measured. The PyPi downloads is a good proxy to how popular the tool is. One factor that contributes to the downloads number is also how popular the entire development ecosystem grows on Cardano, which may be out of the hands of the proposer, but this is still a tangible measure anyway. One thing is maybe to add the total amount of downloads by the end of the development cycle to track the overall popularity of Pycardano as it's possible that many developers downloaded it from PyPi in the mid-cycle, hence resulting in less than 200 weekly downloads by the end. 

I also like how for each milestone, the metrics are progressing. By end of week 26 of funding, allowing developers to deploy dApps within 15 mins is definitely an ambitious goal, but that's how many popular frameworks in python are doing. E.g., Django will allow developers to deploy web apps within matter of hours. Given that Pycardano has been under active development every week in the past 2 months plus everything is open-sourced, I strongly agree the information and metrics proposed can be used to audit the progress of the project.

solution: Create a library for developers to write off-chain code in Python, so they can be freed from learning and writing off-chain code in Haskell.
experience: The idea proposer created PyCardano, a lightweight Cardano library in Python. Developers can already use the library to build transactions and mint NFTs. The repository also provides many working examples for developers to learn basic usages the library.
